awd_titl_txt: CI-NEW: NIEUW: Novel Incentives and Workflows in Linguistic Data Collection and Annotation
awd_abstract_narration:
Language touches every aspect of human life. People speak and write in order to manage relationships from the personal to the international, to gather and provide information, to negotiate, influence and inspire. Scientists use language to communicate their findings regardless of their field of study. Although researchers have been working for six decades to process language via computer, only in the past several years have their efforts have produced technologies of sufficient maturity that they can affect the lives of the average citizen. Today, some of the most fortunate use computers to search the vast archives of the Internet, to translate material from languages they do not understand into languages they do and to interact with smart devices by giving them natural language commands and queries and receive responses in kind. Despite the growth and promise of human language technologies, they are in fact available for only a tiny portion of the world's approximately 7000 languages and, even then, for only a limited range of situations. This is the case because the approaches that have proven most successful in developing human language technologies require vast amounts of spoken or written language material that have been augmented by human judgment as to their interpretation, but such resources are lacking for most languages and for many types of situations, even for languages of international importance, including English. This Research Infrastructure project will address this shortage of language resources by supporting the language technology research community to employ novel incentives and alternate workflows to greatly expand the methods that have been used to date for collecting and annotating language data. The resulting resources will support research and development on an expanded range of language technologies, leading to the creation and deployment of applications for an increasingly broad range of languages and situations. 

Even a brief observation of user behavior on social media, online games, citizen science and public good initiatives demonstrates that many people around the world are willing to devote collectively vast amounts of effort when given appropriate motivation and effective tools. This project will harness some of the immense people-power that drives such activities and focus it on problems of developing language resources that help computers learn to process language. Specifically, the project will create a software toolkit to be developed by the project team in response to the needs of language technology researchers to create online activities that yield language resources. The activities will include games, citizen science and tools for language professionals, clustered into a series of portals that appeal to different populations of users. The project will build and maintain the database and web servers, with redundancy, load balancing and fail over, to run the principal instance of all of the activities, and an open-source release of the software will enable other researchers to build their own instances independently. Finally, the data resulting from this project will be shared with the least restrictive terms possible to further support language technology research and development activities worldwide.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF CI-New project, NIEUW: Novel Incentives and Workflows in Linguistic Data Collection and Annotation, was funded with the overall goal of creating infrastructure to increase the volume and variety of language resources using novel incentives. The three specific goals of the project were to: 1) extend and modify existing LDC infrastructure and tools to enhance data collection and annotation 2) both use the enhanced infrastructure and tools internally and open access to partners and external users, and 3) build online communities that motivate contributions through alternative workflows and incentives including crowdsourcing, citizen science and games with a purpose (aka, human-based computation games).

For the first goal, we extensively adapted and modified a web-based collection and annotation toolkit previously developed in-house at the Linguistic Data Consortium (LDC) to create an open source, portable package that supports the creation of a variety of linguistic activities and projects suitable for crowdsourced contributions from a wide range of participants. This toolkit was modified to support the annotation of text, audio, image, and video data, and to include an audio recorder feature to allow participants to also make contributions in the form of speech. In addition, our software developers created a stream-lined and easy to use project builder to allow annotation tasks to be created within the web portal by researchers without any programming or coding knowledge required. The software was also improved for ease of use for activity designers especially when laying out GUIs, defining workflows, reporting progress, extracting data, and include algorithms for task assignment and integration of variable responses into stable datasets. The development of an easy-to-use project builder was crucial to allow a variety of external researchers from graduate students to sociolinguists to computational linguists to use the toolkit to create projects.

To provide access to the annotation toolkit and build communities of users, we created three online portals designed to appeal to different user groups and incentive models. The first portal, Lingo Boingo, is a collection of language games and gamified activities which offer the incentives of competition, entertainment, and opportunity to learn while playing fun games. The portal contains eight language-based games developed by external colleagues and one LDC created language identification game, Name That Language. Our primary portal, LanguageARC, features our underlying annotation toolkit and project builder and is available to researchers to create data collection and annotation activities. In contrast to the games portal that appeals to fun and competition, LanguageARC is a citizen science research hub and community that offers members of the public interested in language opportunities to learn about and make direct contributions to research on language and to join groups of like-minded contributors. Since its public debut in 2019, Language ARC has been successfully used to create dozens of annotation projects in multiple languages, including some that have met their annotation goals and are no longer active. As of August 2023, there are fifteen active projects in half a dozen different languages on the portal with new projects added on an ongoing basis. Our third port, Machina Pro Linguistica, is built on the same annotation toolkit as Language ARC but includes a more powerful transcription tool and is designed for use by language professionals, teachers, and students.

Over the past few years, we have extensively promoted this project to the research community at academic workshops and conferences such as LREC, Interspeech, and NWAV. We have also built and grown a community of participants through ongoing publicity and promotion of the Language ARC and Lingo Boingo portals on all the major social media networks, academic networks such as LinguistList, and through citizen science organizations such as SciStarter.

And applications based on NIEUW-created software are being used by a large and growing number of organizations and individuals.
